Description: Fragment of a limestone column drum with 25 shallow flutings. The flutings feature a few slight drag marks that deepen towards the centre. The upper and under surface are even and without traces of tools, however the ridges are strongly rubbed. The light limestone fragments shows traces of paint on the surface.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis) (Attributed by Petrie to the 'first temple of Apollo'.)
Curator's comments: The diameter corresponds to the reconstructed diameter of the column above the base B391 and is smaller than the diameter of B396 and B397 because of the lack of leaf wreaths. The uneven number of fluting is unusual. Published (Petrie 1886, 12 par. 16; Koenigs 2007, 314 Cat. 2; Smith 1892, no. 100). Joined to restored fragments 1886,4-1.24-26.3.
Bibliographic references: Sculpture / Catalogue of Greek Sculpture in the British Museum (B392)
Koenigs 2007 / Archaische griechische Bauteile (p. 314-5, pl. 2,4,5, 11, cat. no. 2, 3)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (AA.04) (Phase 3)
